title: Montana Senate passes public record request bill
excerpt: What constitutes a “timely” response to public records requests could become quite a bit clearer if Senate Bill 232 passed the Montana Legislature. The proposal by Sen. Janet Ellis, D-Helena, unanimously passed the Senate on March 2.

title: Montana Senate votes forward statewide TikTok ban
excerpt: The Montana Senate has voted to advance a statewide ban on Chinese-owned social media platform TikTok, calling the service a threat to privacy, national security and public safety. It still needs approval from the Montana House and Gov. Greg Gianforte.

title: Legislature reaches its 2023 midpoint
excerpt: Hundreds of proposed laws at the Montana Legislature officially landed in Capitol recycling bin Friday as they failed to clear the session’s March 3 transmittal deadline, the date most non-budget bills introduced this session were required to clear at least one legislative chamber.

title: House advances dueling charter school bills
excerpt: A pair of Republican-led charter school proposals have passed their initial votes on the House floor, one of them tied to a sprawling educational reform package. It’s the first time in at least two decades that even one charter pitch has made it this far.

title: Montana Senate endorses legislative subpoena powers bill

nodes.name: Special Select Committee on Judicial Accountability and Transparency

excerpt: The Montana Senate has given preliminary approval to a bill that aims to clarify the Legislature’s power to conduct investigations and obtain documents through subpoenas, advancing a measure drafted as a result of a protracted separation-of-powers fight between Republican lawmakers and the Montana Supreme Court.

title: Where Montana’s special election committee stands

nodes.name: joint select committee on election security

excerpt: The Joint Select Committee on Election Security has spent months exploring the nuances of Montana’s election system. That work has crystallized in three proposals targeting absentee voter list maintenance and voting machine procedures, all of which won bipartisan support in the Senate.

title: Information blackout shrouds new reports of harm at Montana State Hospital

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: Patient injuries, abuse, and neglect have continued at the Montana State Hospital since the state-run psychiatric facility lost its federal certification last year due to preventable patient deaths. But state officials won’t release details, citing laws making those reports confidential. The lack of information frustrates some lawmakers as they consider state health officials’ and Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte’s request for a $300 million appropriation to overhaul the state’s mental health system and a nearly $20 million request for capital improvements and recertification efforts at the state hospital.

title: Billion-dollar tax rebate, spending package heads to governor’s desk
excerpt: A suite of bills allocating a billion-dollar chunk of Montana’s $2.5 billion-plus surplus toward tax rebates and other spending measures cleared the final Senate votes standing between them and the desk of Gov. Greg Gianforte this week. If, as is likely, Gianforte signs the bills into law, they would tee up the state to issue income tax rebates of up to $1,250 per taxpayer and property tax rebates of up to $1,000 per homeowner. Combined, those rebate efforts would pull an estimated $764 million from state coffers.

title: Committee votes on four wolf bills as legislative deadline nears
excerpt: Two wolf-related bills will advance to the full House for a vote, while two others are likely dead in process following votes cast by the House Fish, Wildlife and Parks Committee on Feb. 28

title: Broadband spending sideboards get initial House approval
excerpt: Lawmakers in the Montana House gave a preliminary thumbs-up to a bill that would expand legislative oversight of the state’s federally funded broadband internet program, which will likely direct hundreds of millions of dollars to subsidizing rural Montana connectivity in the coming years.

title: Bill calling for accountability in Montana’s Native education moving through Legislature
excerpt: Windy Boy’s bill would require the Office of Public Instruction and the state’s public schools to create and manage a report that details exactly how that school incorporated Indian Education for All into its classrooms.

title: Bill creates strict definition for ‘sex,’ legally sidelining intersex and transgender people
excerpt: A bill to create a rigid definition of ‘sex’, boxing out legal recognition of intersex, nonbinary and transgender people in far-flung references across state law, passed a Senate public health committee late Monday after more than an hour of testimony from opposing sides.

title: Montana Indian Child Welfare Act passes key House vote
excerpt: A legislative bill that would solidify protections for Native American children in Montana has gained support from the state’s House of Representatives, which approved the bill during its second reading.

title: Sex ed drives raft of public education proposals
excerpt: Concerns about sex education in Montana’s K-12 public schools have fueled a series of proposals about what gets taught and how parents are notified, with much of the debate rooted in a controversial law passed by the 2021 Legislature.

title: Breaking down the ‘status sheet’
excerpt: The status sheet is one of the main tools lawmakers use to ensure that the hundreds of bills under active consideration in the Capitol will produce the balanced budget required by the state Constitution.

title: Health insurance trust for school employees tabled
excerpt: House Bill 332, sponsored by Rep. David Bedey, R-Hamilton, was tabled Friday by the House Appropriations Committee on a 13-10 vote. Bedey and other supporters, including the Montana School Boards Association, argued that such a trust would help drive down costs for struggling districts and increase take-home pay for teachers.

title: $2 billion coal trust proposal gets a hearing
excerpt: A proposal to invest $2 billion from the state’s General Fund into the coal severance tax trust fund is gaining traction, having attracted an unconventional assortment of lawmakers from both parties.

title: Fish and Wildlife Commission gains two new members
excerpt: The Senate has confirmed four nominees to the state Fish and Wildlife Commission, the seven-member body charged with setting hunting and angling regulations and reviewing Montana Fish, WIldlife and Parks land acquisitions.

title: Senate Judiciary tables two court appointment bills
excerpt: The Senate Judiciary Committee halted a pair of Republican proposals that would change the judicial selection process.

title: Montana seeks to insulate nursing homes from future financial crises
excerpt: Lawmakers are trying to reduce the risk of more nursing home closures through measures that would raise and set standards for the Medicaid reimbursement rates that nursing homes depend on for their operations.

title: Bills seek to permit citizen grand juries in Montana

nodes.name: Montana State Council on Judicial Accountability

excerpt: A pair of bills introduced in the Montana House of Representatives would allow citizens to form grand juries via petition, an idea historically popular in the right-wing militia movement that revives a failed 2010 ballot initiative.

title: Drag ban bill for public places, schools and libraries moves through Legislature
excerpt: Republicans in Montana’s House of Representatives gave initial approval Thursday to a bill banning drag performances in public schools, libraries and public properties “in any location” when a minor is present, legislation blasted by LGBTQ people as hateful and misinformed but welcomed by conservative parental rights groups.

title: Legislature revisits education tax credit debate
excerpt: After a single school district claimed more than half of Montana’s tax-credit-eligible contributions in 2022, lawmakers are searching for a fix. But so far, Democrats and Republicans remain divided on what that solution should look like.

title: Republican legislators advance abortion restrictions, shut down protections for reproductive rights
excerpt: As the Legislature nears a critical deadline for transmitting bills, lawmakers are advancing new abortion regulations and rejecting measures to protect reproductive health access.

title: Land planning overhaul would prioritize proactive urban planning
excerpt: Senate Bill 382 would require additional planning by local governments, rework how and when residents can participate in planning decisions and, supporters say, make it easier to build the housing necessary to accommodate rapid population growth.

title: Lawmakers narrowly reject prohibition on medical aid in dying
excerpt: A bill that would have criminalized Montana physicians who provide terminally ill patients with medical aid in dying narrowly failed to pass a final vote in the Senate chamber Wednesday, spelling the likely fate of the bill this session.

title: Forever no more? Bill seeks to restrict state’s access to perpetual conservation easements
excerpt: A bill that would roll back the state’s ability to purchase permanent conservation easements garnered opposition from an unlikely collection of opponents. Logging and agricultural groups were joined by conservation organizations and hunting and fishing groups in their request that the Senate FIsh and Game Committee table Senate Bill 357.

title: Committee advances bill that proponents say needed to protect cultural identity of Native children
excerpt: The House Human Services Committee voted 15-6 to pass HB 317 with two amendments. The bill was first introduced and heard in committee earlier this month during a hearing that attracted over 30 proponents. A letter of support from the Legislature’s American Indian Caucus was also introduced.

title: Legislative committee tables right-to-work bill
excerpt: The House Business and Labor Committee voted 12-7 to table a bill establishing Montana as a right-to-work state.

title: Affordable housing advocates push to put state dollars toward price-controlled housing
excerpt: Housing affordability advocates are working to drum up support in the Montana Capitol for a pair of bills that would put state resources into supporting the construction of more price-controlled housing for middle- and low-income Montanans — policies that would take a step beyond the free-market strategies that have so far drawn support from Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte.

title: Lawmakers eye deep changes to K-12 education
excerpt: During the 2021-22 interim, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle took a hard look at the “case for change” in K-12 education. Now those conversations are manifesting in proposals that could mean major change for Montana’s public school students and teachers.

title: Montana’s federal delegation addresses state Legislature
excerpt: The Montana Legislature heard a series of addresses from the state’s federal delegation — at least three of whom could well be vying for the same U.S. Senate seat come 2024.

title: Right-to-work resurfaces at the Montana Legislature, as do dozens of pro-union opponents
excerpt: The Capitol was awash in shades of hi-vis yellow and orange as dozens of union workers testified in opposition to proposed legislation that would establish Montana as the country’s 28th right-to-work state.

title: Bill would let cities tax Airbnbs to subsidize long-term rentals
excerpt: A bill under consideration at the Montana Legislature would give cities, counties and resort districts the option of levying a tax on Airbnb-style, short-term rentals if they use the money to give rebates to landlords who rent to local workers on a long-term basis.

title: Republican lawmakers shy away from changing state’s constitutional right to abortion
excerpt: Montana Republicans may have a legislative supermajority, but they aren’t debating a constitutional change to break the link between abortion and the constitutional privacy.

title: Bill would shrink Montana Supreme Court from seven justices to five
excerpt: Proposed legislation would reduce the number of associate justices on the Montana Supreme Court from six to four over the next several years.

title: E-bike bill advances in key House floor vote
excerpt: A measure that would explicitly open much of Montana’s state-managed lands and trails to e-bikes is set to pass the House following a 54-46 vote.

title: GOP bills would require re-votes on some local property taxes
excerpt: A slate of bills advanced by a prominent Republican lawmaker would try to lower Montana property taxes by requiring revotes on some local tax levies while also raising the approval margins required to pass levies and bond measures in low-turnout local elections.

title: Republicans vote down long-term property tax relief bill
excerpt: House Republicans voted down a Democrat-backed bill Wednesday that would have used income tax credits to ease the squeeze placed on lower-income homeowners and renters by rising property taxes.

title: Lawmakers debate free speech, respect for transgender students
excerpt: Lawmakers in the Montana House held an pointed debate Wednesday on a Republican-backed bill prohibiting schools from disciplining students who misgender their transgender peers. House Bill ultimately passed its first vote largely along party lines.

title: Soliciting support on the public dime
excerpt: The House State Administration Committee on Wednesday approved House Bill 412, a bill sponsored by Rep. David Bedey, R-Hamilton, that expands an existing prohibition on the use of public time or resources for solicitation of political campaign support to apply to legislators and judges. Current state law prohibiting such campaigning specifies its application only to a “public officer or public employee.”

title: Chris Gallus confirmed as Commissioner of Political Practices
excerpt: Gallus, a longtime attorney and lobbyist for the Montana Chamber of Commerce and several conservative-aligned causes, replaces Jeff Mangan.

title: Montana Senate votes against Indigenous Peoples holiday
excerpt: The Montana state Senate voted Tuesday afternoon against discussing a bill that would have established Indigenous Peoples Day in the state following debate over how the new holiday would replace Columbus Day.

title: Bill would enshrine abortion rights in state law
excerpt: A bill introduced this week in the Montana Legislature flipped the typical script for hearings on abortion access: Instead of opposing restrictive bills, reproductive rights advocates lined up to support legislation they said would uphold privacy protections by codifying legal abortion in state law. Opponents urged lawmakers to vote down the bill, calling it “radical” and an “all encompassing piece of pro-abortion legislation.”

title: Educators, OPI push back on teacher licensing fee proposal
excerpt: Montana’s educator licensing fee has remained static at $6 for three decades. Now a bill to increase those fees enough to support the state’s licensing system is prompting polite pushback from teachers and the Office of Public Instruction.

title: Lawmakers prepare to vote on health department’s $7 billion budget request

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: Lawmakers on two key committees plan to take preliminary votes this week on major funding requests for Montana’s health department, the largest state agency tasked with running the state psychiatric hospital, child welfare services, state Medicaid programs and much more.

title: Landlords push back on pro-tenant, mobile-home park bills
excerpt: A pair of Republican-sponsored bills intended to help mobile-home park residents weather Montana’s acute housing shortage drew vehement opposition from park owners, real estate agents and the Montana Landlord Association in their initial hearings Monday morning.

title: Confirmation process for new Commissioner of Political Practices underway
excerpt: The Senate State Administration Committee voted unanimously to confirm longtime attorney and lobbyist Chris Gallus as the new commissioner after peppering him with a series of mostly friendly questions about his philosophy on campaign law and approach to the office.

title: Montana considers allowing physician assistants to practice independently
excerpt: As Montana grapples with a health care provider shortage, state lawmakers are trying to find ways to increase access to care. One proposal up for debate is to give physician assistants more independence to practice unsupervised. Republican Rep. Jodee Etchart is sponsoring House Bill 313, which would let physician assistants practice without a supervision agreement.

title: Drag show bill sets up clash between LGBTQ expression and conservative parental control
excerpt: A bill that would ban drag shows in public schools, libraries and some businesses unleashed a wave of testimony Thursday, pitting LGBTQ people, public employees and local arts organizations against conservative parents’ groups who cast drag performance — and gender nonconformity more broadly — as inherently harmful to children.

title: Marijuana advertising bill hearing highlights confusion over existing law
excerpt: A hearing on a bill to prohibit marijuana advertising revealed a wide gulf between understandings of the state’s current ad policy for the industry.

title: Legislature weighs bill to exempt some small subdivisions from MEPA review
excerpt: Proponents of Senate Bill 240 say it will allow the Montana Department of Environmental Quality to devote its resources to larger projects with more pressing water quality concerns. Opponents say it could facilitate development of agricultural land in “pop-up subdivisions.”

title: Lawmakers make another bid for Indigenous Peoples Day
excerpt: More than 30 people gathered in support of a Senate bill that would establish Indigenous People’s Day as a Montana state holiday. If the bill passes, Indigenous People’s Day would land on the second Monday of October and eliminate Columbus Day as an official state holiday.

title: Bills concerning transgender youth and local control surface in House
excerpt: A pair of legislative proposals have sparked considerable debate across the Montana House about their potential impacts on transgender youth and local control in the state’s public school system.

title: Montana students balk at ‘just the facts’
excerpt: A string of Helena middle and high school students testified before the Senate Education and Cultural Resources Committee on Monday. They sought to explain how a bill restricting public school science curriculum to “scientific fact” that is “observable and repeatable” would put them at an academic disadvantage and undermine instruction on a host of widely accepted scientific theories.

title: Montana’s tax-exempt hospitals oppose increased oversight by state officials

nodes.name: Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: As Montana officials seek to make nonprofit hospitals prove the benefits they provide the community justify their tax exemptions, industry leaders propose their own changes — which state officials say would further limit the state’s authority.

title: Ban on transgender medical care for youth advances
excerpt: A bill to ban gender-affirming medical care for transgender minors cleared an initial vote in the Montana Senate Tuesday after an hour of intense debate and occasional rule maneuvering between lawmakers, the highest profile clash yet this session on the issue that has generated national debate in recent years.

title: Can voting machines be hacked?
excerpt: The Legislature’s election security select committee got a chance to direct inquiries straight to ES&S, the company that supplies the machines.

title: What exactly does a 2,500-square-foot lot look like?
excerpt: House Bill 337 would force Montana cities to allow home lots as small as 2,500 square feet anywhere they provide municipal water and sewer access. But what exactly does a 2,500-square-foot lot look like?

title: Montana Republicans show support for medical conscience bill
excerpt: State lawmakers in the House of Representatives gave broad approval Monday to a bill that would allow medical providers, health care facilities and insurers to deny services based on “ethical, moral, or religious beliefs or principles,” signaling the bill’s likely advancement to the Senate this week.

title: The Montana Legislature’s seating chart
excerpt: House Bill 271, sponsored by Rep. Paul Tuss, D-Havre, would seat lawmakers in the state House and Senate alphabetically by last name, replacing the seating arrangements currently defined by party segregation and hashed out by legislative leadership with statutory direction.

title: Montana remains one of two states without distracted driving laws
excerpt: In Montana, Republicans such as state Sen. Jeremy Trebas not only don’t support a statewide ban, but they also want to overrule Missoula and the 14 other Montana cities, towns, and tribal governments that have enacted bans on hand-held cellphone use while driving.

title: Montana Lawmakers seek more information about governor’s HEART fund

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services
Healing and Ending Addiction Through Recovery and Treatment initiative

excerpt: Gov. Greg Gianforte wants to put more state money into the Healing and Ending Addiction Through Recovery and Treatment initiative, but lawmakers and mental health advocates are asking for more accountability and clarity on how the money is spent.

title: 48 hours in Helena
excerpt: Elected by their geographic peers, 150 citizen legislators representing every slice of the state head to Helena every two years to make laws. What develops is a distinct, if temporary, social ecosystem of its own within the capital city, a self-contained society swirling with veteran and freshman lawmakers, lobbyists, journalists, temporary employees and average citizens with agendas to advocate and bones to pick.

title: Indian Child Welfare Act would protect future generations, advocates say
excerpt: A bill to cement existing federal protections in state law for Native American children, families and tribal nations navigating child welfare proceedings received broad support from Indigenous child welfare advocates during a packed hearing at the Montana Legislature.

title: Tax rebate package muscled through initial House votes
excerpt: The bills would also cut the state business equipment tax, cut capital gains taxes, pay down state debt and allocate $100 million to a highway construction fund.

title: Proposal advances to eliminate educator council
excerpt: A bill eliminating Montana’s 35-year-old advisory council on educator standards passed out of the House this week, part of Gov. Greg Gianforte’s broader red-tape relief effort.

title: Legislative efforts to reshape judicial procedures are gaining steam
excerpt: On Tuesday, Rep. Kerri Seekins-Crowe, R-Billings, presented House Bill 326 to the House Judiciary Committee. The bill proposes giving the Legislature more of a role in the appointment of the Judicial Standards Commission, the body tasked with reviewing complaints of judicial misconduct.

title: Bill would force Montana cities to allow smaller home lots
excerpt: A bill heard Tuesday at the Montana Legislature aims to increase the number of modestly priced homes available to Montana residents by reining in the power of city and town governments to require that new homes be built on properties of a certain size.

title: Trust, perception and Montana elections

nodes.name: joint select committee on election security

excerpt: Heading into the 2023 session, Montana was primed for a pitched policy debate over the integrity and security of its election process. Now the conversation among lawmakers has kicked loose questions about trust, perception and how extensive the case for change truly is.

title: Committee debates medical ‘right of conscience’ bill
excerpt: A bill that would allow medical institutions, providers and other health care employees to deny services based on their “ethical, moral, or religious beliefs or principles” was the subject of intense debate Monday during an initial committee hearing, setting up a conflict over rights of providers and patients.

title: Lawmakers debate ban on gender-affirming care for transgender minors
excerpt: Roughly 150 people gave passionate testimony Friday morning on Senate Bill 99, a proposal to ban gender-affirming care for transgender minors and restrict the use of public resources for medical and social transitions. After more than five hours of commentary, opponents outnumbered proponents by more than two-to-one.

title: Child welfare reforms sail through major votes
excerpt: A stack of child welfare reforms sailed through major votes in the House and Senate as the 68th Legislature steadily progresses through its 90-day session. The trend of late-January bill passages kicked off with the unanimous approval on Wednesday for House Bill 37, the product of nearly two years of lawmaker study and a heavy round of revisions after its first committee hearing this month.

title: Gianforte delivers second State of the State
excerpt: Fiscal policy, state institutions take center stage over conservative social priorities in Gov. Greg Gianforte’s 2023 State of the State address.

title: Lawmakers pitch health insurance trust for schools
excerpt: Education advocates trumpeted the rollout Wednesday of a bipartisan bill to establish a school health insurance trust, a $60 million investment that the head of Montana’s public employee union called the “most meaningful proposal so far” aimed at tackling the ongoing teacher shortage.

title: Abortion privacy bill clears major vote on Senate floor
excerpt: A bill to statutorily define Montana’s constitutional right to privacy as not including the right to abortion passed a key vote in the Senate chamber Wednesday, leaving one more hurdle before it can continue its trajectory to a House committee.

title: The Legislature’s newest member
excerpt: The Legislature’s newest member is Rep. Naarah Hastings, R-Billings, whom the Yellowstone County Board of Commissioners selected this week to replace former Republican Rep. Mallerie Stromswold.

title: Lawmakers, advocates prepare to fight legislative ‘attacks’ against LGBTQ people
excerpt: For the second consecutive legislative session, advocates for LGBTQ civil rights are gearing up to protest a bill restricting transgender health care, as well as other proposals they say would discriminate against and further stigmatize LGBTQ people.

title: How to spend a $2.5 billion surplus? Lawmakers have no shortage of ideas.
excerpt: Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte has proposed a budget that would fill the state’s reserve accounts, patch up health and social service programs, and put $525 million into short-term property tax rebates. Various factions within the legislative GOP have their own ideas, however, with some Republicans wanting deeper rebates that also focus on refunding income taxes. For their part, super-minority party Democrats have proposed tax relief legislation they say better targets rebates to lower-income Montanans.

title: Bill would reverse ballot issue requirements created in 2021 session
excerpt: A Republican lawmaker and a group of unlikely bedfellows from across the political spectrum are working to repeal a law that erected additional hurdles to getting an issue placed on the ballot.

title: Legislative curtain opens on Gianforte’s ‘red-tape relief’ push
excerpt: A trio of bills that constitute the most prominent thrust of Gov. Greg Gianforte’s sprawling red- tape relief push drew praise and pushback in their initial hearings before a legislative committee this week.

title: Montana Freedom Caucus launches with Rosendale as its north star
excerpt: The Montana Legislature is getting its own Freedom Caucus with Sen. Theresa Manzella, R-Hamilton, at the helm.

title: Five child welfare bills to watch this legislative session
excerpt: Lawmakers, advocates and the state health department are poised to consider dozens of bills during the 68th Legislature to reform parts of the child protection and foster care systems. Stakeholders say the issue will likely be a defining policy priority of the session and an arena well-suited for bipartisan compromise.

title: Public, legislators debate obscenity law revisions
excerpt: A national debate over books some parents view as obscene or pornographic has spilled into the Montana Legislature, leading to a proposal that opponents argue would expose teachers and librarians to potential criminal penalties.

title: Bill to increase per diem rates moves through the Legislature
excerpt: The House gave preliminary approval Jan. 16 to a bill that would increase per diem rates for the lodging and meals of legislators during the session, a biennial hot potato that often sees lawmakers voting against their interest in order to avoid the thorny optics of supporting a greater payout for their time in Helena.

title: Bill would address ‘prison gerrymandering’ in Montana
excerpt: A proposal making its way through the Senate seeks to change how incarcerated Montanans are counted for the purposes of redistricting, ending the practice — at least for those in state institutions – of “prison gerrymandering.”

title: Lawmakers eye changes to teacher retirement system
excerpt: Among the growing number of proposals designed to address Montana’s teacher shortage is House Bill 117, a measure designed to increase how much re-employed retirees in classrooms can earn without risking their retirement benefits.

title: First abortion bill of 2023 introduced in Montana Legislature
excerpt: Despite being less than one page long, proponents and opponents testified Tuesday that Senate Bill 154 would have a profound impact on the state’s reproductive rights landscape by explicitly exempting the right to an abortion from the Montana Constitution’s clause enshrining the right to privacy. That provision was the foundation of the Montana Supreme Court’s 1999 decision in Armstrong v. State that legalized pre-viability abortion in Montana.

title: Bill would require rental application fee refunds
excerpt: A bill under consideration by the Montana Legislature aims to ease the burden of rental application fees on apartment-seeking Montanans by specifying that landlords and property management companies must reimburse unsuccessful applicants for any fees not used for specific expenses like credit checks.

title: Billings Rep. Mallerie Stromswold resigns
excerpt:
Rep. Mallerie Stromswold, R-Billings, is resigning her seat in the Legislature, she announced Saturday morning.

“It is with mixed emotions that I announce my resignation as the Representative for House
District 50, effective immediately,” she wrote in a statement. “Serving the Billings community has been an incredible privilege that I don’t take lightly. The people I’ve met along this journey taught me so much, and I’ve developed many friendships I’ll keep with me throughout my life.”

Stromswold, 21, cited not only the difficulty of balancing student life with legislative service, but also “significant backlash from members of my caucus because I did not fall in line.”

title: Election security committee has its session debut

nodes.name: joint select committee on election security

excerpt: A special committee established by the Montana Legislature to discuss election security issues held its first meeting, giving Montanans a glimpse into where the group will focus its attention this session.

title: Legislature to begin assembling feedback on new House and Senate maps
excerpt: The Legislature’s joint committee on redistricting will hold public testimony and adopt a resolution to provide feedback on how Montana establishes its new legislative districts.

title: Following the 2023 session? Here’s how to do your part.
excerpt: From registering for remote testimony to finding your senators and representatives, Montana Free Press has prepared this comprehensive guide for civic engagement with the Montana Legislature.

title: Launching MTFP’s 2023 Capitol Tracker
excerpt: The 2023 Capitol Tracker, an update to interactive legislative guides we published in 2021 and 2019, aims to make comprehensive data on the quantifiable aspects of this year’s Legislature readily available to our readers. It includes scads of information on lawmakers, bills and votes.

title: Medicaid and abortion top health agenda for Montana lawmakers
excerpt: Montana lawmakers said lowering costs and expanding patient access will be their top health care goals for the new legislative session. But they also will have to contend with making changes to Medicaid, a management crisis at the Montana State Hospital, and proposals to regulate abortion.

title: Lawmakers link up over bipartisan sausage
excerpt: The sight as a group of Montana lawmakers gathered at an event venue outside Clancy Saturday morning, a week into the 2023 session of the Montana Legislature, wasn’t necessarily pretty.

title: House rules package passes key hurdle
excerpt: An amended set of rules to govern the Montana House of Representatives passed a key preliminary vote after heated debate within the Republican caucus.

title: For Montana Legislature, the biennial work begins
excerpt: The 68th Montana Legislature has convened, its first day marking a relative calm before what could be a watershed session steered by the first Republican bicameral supermajority since the state adopted its current Constitution in 1972.

title: GOP leadership confirms formation of election integrity committee
excerpt: Montana lawmakers will launch a special committee next month to discuss the issue of election integrity. The committee won’t have bill-passing power, but will include several legislators critical of the current security of state elections.

title: Legislative committee releases final report in judiciary conflict

nodes.name: Special Select Committee on Judicial Accountability and Transparency

excerpt: A Republican-led legislative select committee created in the heat of an inter-branch conflict with the judiciary has identified several proposals it says could address the allegations of bias at the heart of the fight, including restrictions on judicial lobbying and clarifying the Legislature’s subpoena powers.

title: House and Senate committees pass preliminary legislative rules
excerpt: Lawmakers kept the lid on simmering conflict between Republican factions and passed amended versions of the rules that govern legislative procedure and decorum in advance of formal votes that will codify those rules in the 2023 session.

title: Gianforte budget proposal puts state surplus toward tax cuts, infrastructure and Montana State Hospital
excerpt: Gov. Greg Gianforte said Thursday the budget proposal he’ll submit to next year’s Montana Legislature will include more than $1 billion in income and property tax cuts while also using the state’s budget surplus to create a child tax credit, spur housing development and invest in health care and correctional facilities.

title: Longtime Butte Democrat Art Noonan dead at 70
excerpt: Art Noonan, one-time executive director of the Montana Democratic Party and member of an influential old guard of Irish-American Butte lawmakers, has died.
